docs.lead_paragraph: A top Senate Democrat is not optimistic that major changes to the health care system will be enacted this year.

headline.main: A Senate Liberal's Health Care Pessimism

docs.abstract: Senator Herb Kohl of Wisconsin hopes he will not have to settle for incremental improvements in the health care system.
docs.snippet: Senator Herb Kohl of Wisconsin hopes he will not have to settle for incremental improvements in the health care system.

docs.lead_paragraph: The clash over health-care reform now centers on the public option: Should it stay or should it go?
docs.abstract: How important, and essential, to the health-care reform debate is the public option?
docs.snippet: How important, and essential, to the health-care reform debate is the public option?

docs.lead_paragraph: Perhaps President Obama has "lost control of the argument" over health care and doesn't have the "political muscle" to get his proposals enacted, it was suggested on Wednesday to Robert Gibbs, the president's chief spokesman.

headline.main: White House: 'The Argument Is Not Over'

docs.abstract: The president still prefers a public option, his chief spokesman said, but is open to other means of encouraging competition among insurers.
docs.snippet: The president still prefers a public option, his chief spokesman said, but is open to other means of encouraging competition among insurers.

docs.lead_paragraph: House Democrats sent letters to the nation's top insurance companies this week, asking the firms to detail the compensation paid to their executives, as well as company revenue and profits.

headline.main: House Queries Insurance Companies on Executive Pay

headline.main: House Queries Insurance Companies on Executive Pay

docs.lead_paragraph: Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on CBS: You think it's hot here in New York City, it's also hot down in Washington, D.C. It's so hot in Washington, D.C. that today, President Obama invited Professor Henry Louis Gates Jr. and Sergeant Crowley to the White House to run through the sprinkler.

docs.lead_paragraph: The debate over whether the government should offer a public insurance plan is all about competition. How competitive is the private insurance market right now? It depends on where you live.

headline.main: For Many Consumers, Few Insurance Choices

docs.abstract: In nine states, a single insurer covers more than 70 percent of the populace. In 17 others, one insurer covers more than half of the people.
docs.snippet: In nine states, a single insurer covers more than 70 percent of the populace. In 17 others, one insurer covers more than half of the people.

docs.lead_paragraph: If it's opinions you want about health care - whether to nod in agreement or gnash your teeth - today's Times editorial and op-ed pages are ready to serve.

headline.main: Advocating a Public Plan, Co-ops and Flash Mobs

docs.abstract: In today's Times, editorialists defend both co-ops and a public option.
docs.snippet: In today's Times, editorialists defend both co-ops and a public option.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama will try to pump some gas into overhauling health care again on Wednesday, but not before he greets a few citizens who make a living pressing the pedal to the floor.
docs.abstract: Administration officials press ahead on health care.
docs.snippet: Administration officials press ahead on health care.

docs.lead_paragraph: Oncology nurse Theresa Brown is a regular contributor to Well.

headline.main: A Nurse's View of Health Reform

docs.abstract: My patient was savvy about the business side of health insurance, but not about how cruel and unfair life can be.
docs.snippet: My patient was savvy about the business side of health insurance, but not about how cruel and unfair life can be.
